awd_titl_txt: IDR:  Optical Imaging of High pH Dependent Degradation in Infrastructure Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Interdisciplinary Research (IDR) project is to study the use of advanced chemical sensing methods to measure the pH values in fresh and aging concrete. This work will be carried out for better understanding the acid/alkali dependent degradation phenomena in concrete structures by measurements with spatial and temporal resolution. The project's approach is specifically designed to study alkali-aggregate reactions in concrete, a major contributor to the premature deterioration of concrete structures. This strongly pH-dependent degradation reaction that takes place between the high pH media of hydrated Portland cement and the surrounding aggregate, produces expansive byproducts that result in the significant cracking of concrete. The proposed method will utilize a chemosensor made from a synthetic porphyrin-based sensor molecule that shows pH-specific changes in its optical spectrum when in contact with the alkali in concrete. The sensor molecule will be mixed into fresh concrete or applied onto fractured concrete surfaces to enable the measurement of pH levels. This research project will combine the expertise of a synthetic chemist for the design and synthesis of suitable pH-sensing chromophores, and the expertise of civil engineers to apply these chromophores in the study of alkali-silica reaction to concrete materials.

If successful, the knowledge created through this grant will enable researchers to better understand the kinetics of alkali ions and the resulting distress in concrete structures. This understanding will ultimately enhance our capabilities in testing, mitigation, remediation, monitoring, early detection and service life prediction of concrete structures.

por.por_cntn:
Infrastructure such as roads, bridges, dams, buildings and other public works exist to sustain our economy and facilitate our way of life. Revitalizing our civil infrastructure, making it more durable and supportive, is essential for the well-being of our nation. Reports published by the American Society for Civil Engineers (ASCE) estimated that it will require an investment of $2.2 trillion over a five-year period to bring the nation’s infrastructure up to a state of good repair.

A number of chemical reactions lead to the premature degradation of infrastructure materials. These reactions are the root cause of infrastructure deterioration. in concrete, one of the major modes of such distress is pH-dependent degradation reactions. Despite extensive worldwide research, large gaps remain in understanding the mechanisms of high pH-dependent degradation rections in concrete.

With the support of this grant, we set out to develop a pH-sensitive sensor molecule that would respond to the extreme high pH values in concrete. The sensor molecule operates by changing color as funtion of high pH values. By measuring the color of the dye on concrete, it allows one to then map the pH value of the mateerials. This, in turn, will allow monitoring of the chemical reactions in the concrete, allowing for much better prediction of the structural health.

Much of the funds awarded in this grant were allocated supporting graduate students whos research projects dealt with the above research. One PhD thesis at the University of Connecticut was the result of this effort. This was followed by testing on real concrete samples and research related to imaging for concrete degradations was carried out, resulting in another PhD thesis at NYU. Research results were presented at a number of international conferences and peer-reviewed international publications.
